My recorded playtime is not reflective of actual playtime. I've bought Clear Sky twice now, and I play a modded version now.   So first, I'll give a review of the game by itself, then add a little something for the vets. This is a great tactical fps and rpg game. The gun mechanics feel so good in this game. It's not like most games where bullet spread and accuracy is just enough enough of a factor to notice it in game. Here you you really have to have good aim, and you have to stabilize your gun before you fire. Getting into a battle with a couple bandits with a shotgun in this game feels more epic and real than anything you'll see in a COD or Battlefield or just about any other shooter. The AI is just awesome. Taking cover, blind fire, flanking, retreating, grenades, camping, even sneaking on a rare occasion. The combat mechanics are my favorite part of this game; every gun feels different and realistic, and every encounter gets the adrenalin going.  The art is another thing, some people find the game ugly, but I think it's got the best sun rays and dynamic effects I've ever seen. They had volumetric fog in this around the same time as the AAA games started getting it. There is nothing like the zone though, I find myself screenshotting a lot in this game. Seeing water stream down walls and the sunrays through trees or windows... it's just a beautiful game.  The story is great too, but it is mostly an addition to the story of Call of Chernobyl. That game had a bit of a better story with the whole 'Kill Strelok' mission, but this one simply adds to that. What this story does better than the other STALKER games, and heres where I start talking to the vets, is it takes you through the areas of the zone at a much more balanced and compelling pace. It kinda funnels you through these scenarios that slowly feel more and more epic, because of the gameplay challenges presented.   Now with all that said, I think this is the best of the STALKER games, and I think it's worthy to note that it is cheaper than the others last I saw. Of course they all have their own merits and flaws but I like the mechanics the best in this one, and the challenge. I also believe that it has the best mods available for it, there's a few that combine it with the first stalker which is just perfect I think.

The atmosphere is great, as in any STALKER game, and things are up to the level of SoC and CoP for a while.  Until you decide to get involved in the faction wars (extremely bugged) or until you reach the last 25% of the story: then it's just a military shooter, where enemies will home their granades right between your eyes. Tons and tons of human enemies to kill, but the atmosphere is completely lost. What made SoC and CoP great games was slowly passing though abandoned towns and desolated landscapes, looking for precious artifacts and watching your back from bloodsuckers and other mutants. If you want this in CS, you need to really force it upon the game. On top of that, mind that most (all?) maps and locations are the same of SoC. I played SoC some 4/5 years ago and still got lots of deja vu. It can be nice, realising that you actually know this or that place, but feels a bit lazy somehow.  Overall, I recommend it to STALKER veterans who want a challenge, but perhaps CoP with mods is a better choice. In any case, do not forget to install the Sky Reclaimation Project to fix bugs and enhance the experience. If you have never played a STALKER game, play Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Prypjat first. Those are the real deal.

Ukrainian and Russian post-apocalyptic open world RPG/FPS taking place around a fictional second accident at Chernobyl. Like the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, mod for best results. Clear Sky is the second game in the series and probably the least favored by the community because of it's bugginess. A strong addition though to the three titles Clear Sky takes players to the Zone before the events of Shadow of Chernobyl. Clear Sky's defining mechanic is faction wars, absent from the other two titles, it also features some new areas and some old but differently inhabited.

In the second installation of the wonderful S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise you play a mercenary named Scar. Clear Sky takes place one year prior to the events in the first game. Becoming quite nostalgic about their past in the world of sports, these said individuals recreate their days on the football field with live grenades.

Clear Sky tries to follow its predecessor - and fails miserably.   Just take a look at some of these awesome features!  - Hardly any atmosphere, nothing compared to SoC - Characters that have little to no originality and - well - no character. They just sit there and talk. Or they run around and are meaningless. These will probably die soon. - Even more bugs than the first game - Ridiculous AI (sees you in the dark with your lamp off, behind things, inside foliage... just everywhere, but every time you have allies, they are the worst you could imagine) - Incredibly monotonous gameplay -> Just shoot. Kill entire armies of soldiers on your very own, over and over again. Well, if you can spare some time, deal with brutally pugnacious mutants. It doesn't matter what kind of enemy you encounter - they're all mostly bulletproof, unless you hit them multiple times in the head with high-end gear.  I'll just add that I actually play the community made 'Clear Sky Complete' mod that is meant to 'ENHANCE' the entire thing... seriously don't wanna see the vanilla original.  There is exactly one positive point about this game, but solely for those who played the first one: + Many of the areas from SoC are recognizable, but a little different. Veterans will revel in memories. And the new portions of the map are quite interesting as well.  .........BUT: Don't celebrate too much - 'cause if you just fell in love being 'home' at the Cordon or the Garbage again - well, enjoy, because you most likely won't get there a second time. The story line is just too linear to find any sense in travelling back.    Well - all in all it's really sad. But I wanted to have the entire trilogy, so i got the bundle. At least it was on sale.

5/10, crappy end game. If you're new to Stalker series, play SoC or Call of Pripyat.  Clear Sky has it's moments. There are lots of well designed environments for geocaching. Day/night cycles highlight game's excellent shadow system. Anomaly artifacts are rare enough. Game works a lot like Shadow of Chernobyl in most aspects.  On down side, some missions aren't that much fun on harder difficulty levels, there is little or no benefits from finding hidden caches, Faction Wars seems like afterthought and won't lend much to gameplay after starting area. Looting corpses for money is very easy. But those problems aren't nothing compared how bad end game is which must be probably one of the worst I've played. It's time-constrained pipe-running in midst of one-shotting grenade-spam enemies spawning from thin air. If you eventually grind it through by memorizing enemy positions, bugged end game makes you finally turn difficulty down and restarting from auto-save. Or go to YouTube for end video.

STALKER Clear Sky review, by Filthy Nick  Graphics: ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well the graphics aren't that good, the game runs on the X-RAY 1.5 engine, it's a very old engine, I beleve it was introduced somewhere in 2002. with Oblivion Lost (Yes, STALKER was suposed to be called Oblivion Lost). Xray engine is full of bugs. Damn bugs, anyway this is the Xray engine 1.5 so it's in the 'top form'. It's stable if you use the vanila game. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Gameplay: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- STALKER is one of those games, when you start playing them you just can't stop, it's too good, my favorite thing about this game is the faction war (install Clear Skies mod for the better expiriance), you feel like the factions are in a real war. At the very start of the game you need to clear out the Regenade scum so that Clear Sky can take over the swamp. When you are short on cash there is always artefact hunting, with a detector you can find these things so called artefacts, you can sell them for a nice ammount of cash.  The worst thing is when you are in a fight and then your weapon jams, that one second may be the diference bettwen life and death, that's why you always need to reparir your gear. Clear Sky is the first STALKER game that features weapons/suit upgrades, every upgrade has its pros and cons.  Weapons in this game use a realistic bullet physics, they have tracers and everything, bullets will fall after some time so don't expect to kill somebody that is 200m from you with no calculation or what so ever. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- VERDICT: Would I recomend this game? ♥♥♥♥ yeah I would, I got this on steam just because there was a sale, I have the retail version of the game. Oh yeah , all of you who bought the game as a retail copy I suggest you buy it on steam, steam version is really stable unlike the retail version.  8/10 Engine is old, gameplay is damn good, crashes sometimes, get mods for it, it's way better with mods.

The game isn't terrible, but it's not great either. The game devs were quite cruel when making this game.  -Possible Spoiler Alert-  Pros: -Repair system. This was much needed, as equipment tends to degrade quickly, which can make the game unnecessarily difficult. -Upgrades. Feeling of progression with the ability to improve your weaopns and armor.  Cons: The game devs were really cruel when making this game. -The beginning of the game is pretty dumb. The bandits have all of the advantages against you (better accuracy, can spray accurately, tank more bullets than you), and you're constantly in 1v8 situations with little to no cover. -A powerful sniper rifle (VSS Vintorez) is available at the very beginning of the game. However, it is unusable without paying a hefty repair cost, and the ammunition it uses cannot be obtained until late in the game, at which this sniper is readily available. In short, it's just dead weight. -There's a machine gun emplacement that guns you down while you run for your life. This is impossible on the hardest difficulty, and even on the easiest difficulty, the machine gun will probably warrant a somewhat expensive repair. -At one point in the game, bandits steal all of your money. Adds insult to injury. -Bandits are total ♥♥♥♥♥, but only they can help you install the best armor upgrades.  -Not many side quests. -The is too linear. I found myself passing through each area exactly once with little reason to backtrack. Unlike the other STALKER games, there's no central hub(s) where one can settle down and relax.  Overall, not recommended unless you're a hardcore STALKER fan that wants bragging rights for playing all the games.

One of the most broken games available. Even if you've got a load of extra cash lying around, I wouldn't recommend buying this game. The game seems great at first with wide-open areas and decent visuals but it all goes downhill from there. It seems the vast majority of the game is plagued with radiation that keeps you from exploring it, and all other areas are loaded with bandits and military goons. The biggest problem with the game are the loads of human enemies that litter the world turning it into a standard spray and pray shoot-out, but with a special catch: every single enemy is a bullet sponge that can absorb clip after clip, the only saving grace being that sometimes a headshot will kill them instantly. Other problems rise from certain parts of the game being a pain to get to because of broken hit-boxes or dozens of 'anomalies' being in the way that make traversing slow and mind-numbing. The tutorials also don't explain a whole lot, the UI is mediocre, and secondary quests are a pain to deal with because of a bad map and the many environmental blockages that will get in your way. It would be enjoyable to wander the expansive wastes, but sadly every five steps you take runs you into an irradiated field or an anomaly that will explode into a cloud of lightning and send you flying. Overall, a terrible game with basically no redeeming qualities.

Ok so this is my first S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game and I have to say I LOVE IT. I almost didn't get it however, because of video reviews on youtube. They were all pretty negative but I have to strongly disagree with them and say I'm super glad that I got it. Now here are two things that I have seen so far to be common negatives in reviews but I haven't seen in game: - I have not been sniped with a pistol. - I can easily avoid grenades. (I use easily lightly. I just mean they're not like tactical nukes)  I am, by the way, using no mods. Don't get me wrong though, this game is extremely difficult. Especially if you have no idea what your doing and die from radiation without noticing it and making the same mistake... again.. and again. But to me this makes this game beautiful. It's a harsh world that you just get thrown into. If you save a lot (and I mean A LOT), you should be fine and get a hang of the game pretty quickly without too much frustration.   Another thing I will address is that some people have a problem with the shooting mechanic. I have heard that it's really just rolling the dice. Now I know this sounds bad, I thought it did, but when I actually played, I realized it wasn't as bad as it was said to be. You are going to miss, but this just adds to the realism. And the AI aren't that bad either. The worst I've seen so far is a soldier still firing his gun after all the enemies were killed, which, by my standards, isn't anything incredibly bad. They are kinda tactical and are good to fight alongside.   Now, on the line of atmosphere. IT IS PHENOMENAL. Keep in mind I don't use any mods, so this game is just made this well! Speaking mostly from the swamps, the atmosphere is pretty engaging. From the AIs all moving around and communicating within a real time world to the footsteps you can hear in the bushes alongside the path (I'm not kidding. It's creepy), this atmosphere really plays out the situation well and keeps you engaged.   So if you take anything from this review, just know that your opinion is probably different from another review, so if you're even thinking about getting it.. get it. Trust me it's worth it. DARK SOULS + FALLOUT = S.T.A.L.K.E.R.   8/8 m8 would stalk her again

Had a blast playing this game! If you've played the first game of the series, Shadows of Chernobyl (SoC)—this second installation is a prequal—you'll find lots of similarities, but a few distinct differences. Gone are the moments of terror and tension of 'stalking' through radiation- and anomaly-infested facilities wondering in fear of what may be around the corner. You still do a lot of it—the game world is near identical to the original SoC; however, this time the pace is much more action-oriented.   A new 'faction' mode compels you to spend a lot of your time fending off other humans (bandtis, renegades, military, etc...) in a 'capture-the-flag' type game mode, so a lot of time is spent fending off enemies in weapon-to-weapon situations. If you're a fan of the horror motif of SoC, it's been toned down quite a bit, but if you enjoy working with very intelligent AI to take control of key positions, then you'll find that aspect of the game very engaging.  The upgrade mechanic is also a welcomed mechanic; however, it was frustrating at first using low-end base weapons and watching them miss their mark more often than not. Cost of upgrades were also a little pricey, forcing you to choose very carefully or run the risk of spending additional hours grinding to make enough money to craft a new weapon to your liking.  Overall, definitely worthy of the series, albeit a slightly differenty type of game than the original, but the differences were definitely more of a positive than a negative. Would definitely recommend this game, even if you've never played SoC (but I would recommend playing SoC first, as their are some major spoilers right away that reference aspects of that first game).  Now I'm looking forward to finishing off the trilogy with Call of Pripyat!

The first Swamps level is probably the best thing about Clear Sky -- it really does feel like it is building on Shadow of Chernobyl to greater heights! Unfortunately, it builds the game up to a level it cannot sustain.  It's kind of cool to revist a lot of the same places and see them in a slightly different light. But by the time you are going through the Agroprom and Yantar, the novelty begins to wear off.  Add in the numerous bugs and outright crashes towards the end of the game, even with the Complete mod, and I was seriously getting frustrated towards the end of my 150-hour playthrough. Oh, and the final act feels rushed, just like it did in SoC. And don't even get me STARTED on the final level! Argh!  Still, the nod to the film Stalker in the penultimate level is very nice, though it is a shame the game rushes you through it without too much chance to revel in the environments.  Overall -- definitely weaker and less polished that SoC Complete, but still, I managed to clock up a good amount of hours out of Clear Sky. It never quite manages to surpass its opening, though, which is a shame.

A lot of people have rightly said that Clear Sky was disappointing after Shadow of Chernobyl. I agree, mostly because a lot of the maps are just reworkings from the first game. Also, there is a little less depth in the story, tipping the scale into Clear Sky being more of a straight shooter.  However, the 'factions' war element brings something genuinely new to the game. Moreover, all the great visuals are still there and, when the new maps come along from time to time, they are still a real treat! I like the changes that have been made to the artifacts 'system' as well - there are fewer of them to be had, and they are harder (and more dangerous) to acquire. This adds value to their value.  If you have an itch to replay Chernobyl, but perhaps don't want to play through the exact same game again, get Clear Sky, especially if its on offer. Clear Sky proivdes enough of a difference for you to get your STALKER fix!   People tell me that Pripyat is even better again... I'm saving it though!

Combining my favorite game genres, Stalker is an FPSRPG you just shouldn't miss. A prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl, it takes a lot of maps from the original game and a few new areas of its own, with a new twist and improved gameplay mechanics. It's unique system creates gameplay scenarios you really can't find anywhere else. A game worth playing if you enjoy survival games.   There are plenty of mods to choose from as well, but if you want to play a modded game, you'll usually have to start a new one. You can't decide in the middle of the game you don't like something, and go find a mod to fix it, most require a fresh start entirely. Definitely do-able without mods, though there are some frustrating things that were never fixed (like NPC nade spam) and some bugs or quirks to address. Doesn't hurt to do a little reading up first, to decide if you'd like a vanilla or modded experiance your first time through.
All I can say is, If you haven't played any of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, you need to START!!

Though by far the buggiest and often considered the worst of the STALKER games, the prequel Clear Sky is in its own right a good game, especially when paired with the Clear Sky Complete mod. Unlike Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat, the various factions in the Zone have engaged in open warfare, and you can side with either the Bandits or the Loners, or Duty and Freedom, along with the titular Clear Sky faction. The main game areas comprise of much of the areas present in STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl, along with several new locations. New features introduced in Clear Sky include weapon upgrades and modifications, along with the faction wars feature.  Do note that many players, myself included, consider the Clear Sky Complete mod almost mandatory to enjoy this game.  Now get out of here, Stalker.
